qas.question: Players who are sent off in a game are often faced with what?
Sometimes clubs can do what if they feel that a punishment was too harsh?
Football associations enforce what kind of conduct?
What do players who are sent off in a game never faced with?
What can clubs do if they feel that a punishment was not harsh enough?
What kind of conduct is never enforced by Football associations?
What is never allowed as recourse for player suspensions?

context: Along with the general administration of the sport, football associations and competition organisers also enforce <a2_0>good<a2_0/> conduct in wider aspects of the game, dealing with issues such as comments to the press, clubs' financial management, doping, age fraud and <b4_0>match fixing<b4_0/>. Most competitions enforce <a0_0><b3_0>mandatory suspensions<b3_0/><a0_0/> for players who are sent off in a game. Some on-field incidents, if considered very serious (such as <b5_0>allegations of racial abuse<b5_0/>), may result in competitions deciding to impose heavier sanctions than those normally associated with a red card. Some associations allow for <a1_0><b6_0>appeals<b6_0/><a1_0/> against player suspensions incurred on-field if clubs feel a referee was incorrect or unduly harsh.
